elements.content: A series of calcium compounds with α-diimine ligands, [L−Ca-(μ2-Cl)(THF)2]2 (1, L = L iPr; 2, L = LMes), [(L iPr)2− 2CaK2(THF)] n (3), [(LMes)2−Na(THF)2]2Ca (4), and [Ca(L iPr)2−Li(THF)(μ3-Cl)Li(THF)2(μ3-Cl)]2 (5), where L iPr = [(2,6- i Pr2C6H3)NC(Me)]2 and LMes = [(2,4,6-Me3C6H2)NC(Me)]2, have been synthesized by the reaction of the lithium, sodium, or potassium salts of the reduced ligands (L− or L2−) with calcium chloride. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural dinuclear compounds bridged by chloride ions, compound 3 forms a left-handed 21 helical structure, while 4 features a metallocene-like structure, and 5 forms a laddered aggregate. The ligand exists as the doubly reduced dianionic form in 3−5 and appears as the radical anion in compounds 1 and 2. The coordination modes of the alkali metal and calcium ions in these complexes are discussed.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural dinuclear compounds bridged by chloride ions, compound 3 forms a left-handed 21 helical structure, while 4 features a metallocene-like structure, and 5 forms a laddered aggregate. The ligand exists as the doubly reduced dianionic form in 3-5 and appears as the radical anion in compounds 1 and 2. The coordination modes of the alkali metal and calcium ions in these complexes are discussed.

elements.content: The organic compounds of calcium are of interest because of the close relevance of this element to its lighter congener magnesium, which forms a variety of important organometallic compounds, in particular the Grignard reagents. However, organocalcium compounds have been far less explored than the magnesium analogues due to the low reactivity of the calcium metal and high reactivity of the organocalcium products. On the other hand, this nature would facilitate certain applications such as promoting reactions in low temperature. During the last decades, metallocenes and other cyclopentadienyl-containing compounds of calcium, which were already summarized in several reviews, dominated the organocalcium chemistry. The characteristic feature of nearly all base-free metallocenes of the heavy alkaline earth metals (Ca, Sr, Ba) is a distinctly “bent” geometry in the gaseous phase, while in the crystalline state aggregation can occur, leading to coordination polymers. More recently, the chemistry of organocalcium compounds has been greatly developed in the field of catalysis because calcium is inexpensive and biocompatible. Calcium complexes with a variety of organic ligands, such as β-diketiminates, aminotroponate, aminotropiniminates, silyl-substituted fluorenes, benzyl, trispyrazolylborate, amino-bis(phenol), iminophenol, iminophosphoranes, and triazenides, have found applications in many catalytic reactions such as polymerization of styrene, heterofunctionalization of alkenes, alkynes, and carbodiimides, and dimerization of aldehydes. In general, alkaline earth metals form predominantly the +2 oxidation state in their compounds, as this valence corresponds to the noble gas configuration, and the stabilization of the lower oxidation state (+1) for these elements is very hard due to their highly electropositive nature. In recent years, several classes of stable molecular alkaline earth metal compounds in the +1 oxidation state have been synthesized, for example, the metal−metal bond stabilized dimagnesium compounds [LMgMgL] and calcium(I) compounds with contacts to an arene, [(THF)3Ca{μ-C6H3-1,3,5-Ph3}Ca(THF)3].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The organic compounds of calcium are of interest because of the close relevance of this element to its lighter congener magnesium, which forms a variety of important organometallic compounds, in particular the Grignard reagents. However, organocalcium compounds have been far less explored than the magnesium analogues due to the low reactivity of the calcium metal and high reactivity of the organocalcium products. On the other hand, this nature would facilitate certain applications such as promoting reactions in low temperature. During the last decades, metallocenes and other cyclopentadienyl-containing compounds of calcium, which were already summarized in several reviews, dominated the organocalcium chemistry. The characteristic feature of nearly all base-free metallocenes of the heavy alkaline earth metals (Ca, Sr, Ba) is a distinctly "bent" geometry in the gaseous phase, while in the crystalline state aggregation can occur, leading to coordination polymers. More recently, the chemistry of organocalcium compounds has been greatly developed in the field of catalysis because calcium is inexpensive and biocompatible. Calcium complexes with a variety of organic ligands, such as β-diketiminates, aminotroponate, aminotropiniminates, silyl-substituted fluorenes, benzyl, trispyrazolylborate, amino-bis(phenol), iminophenol, iminophosphoranes, and triazenides, have found applications in many catalytic reactions such as polymerization of styrene, heterofunctionalization of alkenes, alkynes, and carbodiimides, and dimerization of aldehydes. In general, alkaline earth metals form predominantly the +2 oxidation state in their compounds, as this valence corresponds to the noble gas configuration, and the stabilization of the lower oxidation state (+1) for these elements is very hard due to their highly electropositive nature. In recent years, several classes of stable molecular alkaline earth metal compounds in the +1 oxidation state have been synthesized, for example, the metal-metal bond stabilized dimagnesium compounds [LMgMgL] and calcium(I) compounds with contacts to an arene, [(THF)3Ca{μ-C6H3-1,3,5-Ph3}Ca(THF)3].

elements.content: The N,N-chelating α-diimine agents are widely investigated for transition metal coordination compounds because of their use in catalysis. The steric and electronic properties of such ligands can be readily modified by attaching variable substituents on the carbon and nitrogen atoms of the NCCN backbone. In addition, as redox-active ligands, they can take one or two electrons to form the mono- and dianionic species upon reduction, which makes them particularly useful in the synthesis of subvalent metal complexes. For example, the reaction of the reduced ligand [LNa2] with ZnCl2 afforded the dinuclear Zn(I) compounds [LZn−ZnL] (L = α-diimine ligands). The main group metal complexes with α-diimine ligands are also known, including the alkaline earth metal magnesium and calcium complexes such as [(dpp-Bian)2Ca], (dpp-Bian)M(THF)3, and [(dpp-Bian)Ca(THF)2I]2 (dpp-Bian = 1,2-bis[(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)imino]acenaphthene).

For example, the reaction of the reduced ligand [LNa2] with ZnCl2 afforded the dinuclear Zn(I) compounds [LZn-ZnL] (L = α-diimine ligands). The main group metal complexes with α-diimine ligands are also known, including the alkaline earth metal magnesium and calcium complexes such as [(dpp-Bian)2Ca], (dpp-Bian)M(THF)3, and [(dpp-Bian)Ca(THF)2I]2 (dpp-Bian = 1,2-bis[(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)imino]acenaphthene).

elements.content: Recently we have used N-aryl-substituted α-diimine ligands to synthesize a group of low-valent metal−metal-bonded or mononuclear organometallic compounds by the metal reduction methods. In these compounds, the ligand can appear as the neutral, monoanionic, and dianionic form, leading to variable structures. The results proved that these redox noninnocent α-diimine ligands can result in a rich chemistry of their metal complexes in regard to the diversity in structure and properties. In order to further evaluate the application of α-diimine ligands in calcium complexes, in the low oxidation state, we have attempted to synthesize calcium compounds with α-diimine ligands bearing different substituents and negative charges. Herein, we report five calcium complexes of such ligands, [(L iPr)−Ca(μ2-Cl)(THF)2]2 (1), [(LMes)−Ca(μ2-Cl)(THF)2]2 (2), [Ca(L iPr)2− 2K2(THF)] n (3), [(LMes)2−Na(THF)2]2Ca (4), and [Ca(L iPr)2−Li(THF)(μ3-Cl)Li(THF)2(μ3-Cl)]2 (5) The compounds show novel molecular or polymeric structures depending on the ligand properties and reaction conditions, and comparisons among them and with related compounds are discussed.
elements.clean_text: Recently we have used N-aryl-substituted α-diimine ligands to synthesize a group of low-valent metal-metal-bonded or mononuclear organometallic compounds by the metal reduction methods. In these compounds, the ligand can appear as the neutral, monoanionic, and dianionic form, leading to variable structures. The results proved that these redox noninnocent α-diimine ligands can result in a rich chemistry of their metal complexes in regard to the diversity in structure and properties. In order to further evaluate the application of α-diimine ligands in calcium complexes, in the low oxidation state, we have attempted to synthesize calcium compounds with α-diimine ligands bearing different substituents and negative charges. Herein, we report five calcium complexes of such ligands, [(L iPr)-Ca(μ2-Cl)(THF)2]2 (1), [(LMes)-Ca(μ2-Cl)(THF)2]2 (2), [Ca(L iPr)2- 2K2(THF)] n  (3), [(LMes)2-Na(THF)2]2Ca (4), and [Ca(L iPr)2-Li(THF)(μ3-Cl)Li(THF)2(μ3-Cl)]2 (5) The compounds show novel molecular or polymeric structures depending on the ligand properties and reaction conditions, and comparisons among them and with related compounds are discussed.

elements.content: To assess the changes of the oxidation state of the metal ion and ligand and their effects on the structure of the complexes, we prepared the alkali metal salts of the monoanionic and dianionic ligands (L R )−M or (L R )2−M2 (M = Li, Na, K) by alkali metal reduction of the neutral ligand L R . The in situ-generated salts were then reacted with CaCl2 to yield the complexes 1−5 (Scheme ). Notably, the ligands retained their original anionic form in the complexes (L− in 1 and 2 and L2− in 3−5), while the divalent calcium metal ion was not reduced by the dianionic ligands. In previous work, the reaction of MgCl2, L, and potassium metal resulted in the Mg−Mg-bonded compound with the divalent Mg2+ ion being reduced to Mg+. A similar reaction was also carried out for CaCl2, but the expected binuclear calcium(I) compound was not obtained. This may be attributed to the difference of the electropositive nature and atomic radius of Ca and Mg, which leads to the result that the calcium(II) ion could not be reduced under the reaction conditions, or the reduced calcium(I) species could not be efficiently stabilized by the ligands used. Moreover, we have conducted further reduction of the chloride-bridged compounds 1 and 2 by Na or K metal, but have not isolated any products. Nevertheless, theoretical studies suggested that very bulky groups should be able to stabilize the Ca(I)−Ca(I) moieties, and experiments have proven that an arene with a π* orbital can offer the possibility of stabilizing the calcium(I) species.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

To assess the changes of the oxidation state of the metal ion and ligand and their effects on the structure of the complexes, we prepared the alkali metal salts of the monoanionic and dianionic ligands (L R )-M or (L R )2-M2 (M = Li, Na, K) by alkali metal reduction of the neutral ligand L R . The in situ-generated salts were then reacted with CaCl2 to yield the complexes 1-5 (Scheme ). Notably, the ligands retained their original anionic form in the complexes (L- in 1 and 2 and L2- in 3-5), while the divalent calcium metal ion was not reduced by the dianionic ligands. In previous work, the reaction of MgCl2, L, and potassium metal resulted in the Mg-Mg-bonded compound with the divalent Mg2+ ion being reduced to Mg+. A similar reaction was also carried out for CaCl2, but the expected binuclear calcium(I) compound was not obtained. This may be attributed to the difference of the electropositive nature and atomic radius of Ca and Mg, which leads to the result that the calcium(II) ion could not be reduced under the reaction conditions, or the reduced calcium(I) species could not be efficiently stabilized by the ligands used. Moreover, we have conducted further reduction of the chloride-bridged compounds 1 and 2 by Na or K metal, but have not isolated any products. Nevertheless, theoretical studies suggested that very bulky groups should be able to stabilize the Ca(I)-Ca(I) moieties, and experiments have proven that an arene with a π* orbital can offer the possibility of stabilizing the calcium(I) species.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of the Complexes 1-5

elements.content: The reaction of CaCl2 with the monoanionic ligands (L iPr)−Na or (LMes)−Na (prepared in situ) in THF yielded the complexes [(L iPr)−Ca(μ2-Cl)(THF)2]2 (1) and [(LMes)−Ca(μ2-Cl)(THF)2]2 (2) as yellow or dark red crystals. The bimetallic structures of complexes 1 and 2 are rare examples of calcium complexes dimerized by bridging chloride ions and supported by α-diimine ligands, although a few organocalcium complexes bridged by chloride have been reported with other supporting ligands such as 1,2,4-( t Bu)3Cp and CH(CMeNAr-2,6- i Pr2)2. The reaction of CaCl2 with the doubly reduced ligands [L iPrK2], [LMesNa2], or [L iPrLi2] afforded three complexes involving mixed metals M/Ca (M = Li, K, or Na), [Ca(L iPr)2− 2K2(THF)] (3), [(LMes)2−Na(THF)2]2Ca (4), and [Ca(L iPr)2−Li(THF)(μ3-Cl)Li(THF)2(μ3-Cl)]2 (5). In the literature, organometallic species containing both Ca and alkali metal M (M = Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs) are mainly supported by amide, enolate, and alkyl/aryl ligands, and the only M/Ca compound bearing α-diimine ligands is [(dpp-Bian)Li]2Ca. Complexes 1−5 are highly air- and moisture-sensitive and are soluble in THF and ether except for the polymeric structure 3.

elements.content: Reaction of (L iPr)−Na with 1 equiv of CaCl2 gave the dinuclear complex 1. Single crystals for X-ray diffraction studies were grown from THF (Figure ). There is a crystallographic inversion center in complex 1, which is located at the center of the rectangular Ca′−Cl−Ca−Cl′ plane. The Ca···Ca separation is 4.263(1) Å. Each Ca atom is six-coordinated by the two N donors of a ligand, two bridging Cl atoms, and two THF molecules. The two Ca−N bonds are significantly nonequivalent, with Ca−N1 (2.575(3) Å) being longer than Ca−N2 (2.372(3) Å). The Ca−Cl bond lengths (2.7145(11) and 2.7521(11) Å) are close to the values found for related compounds [1,2,4-( t Bu)3CpCaCl·DME]2 (av 2.746 Å) and phosphacyclopentadienyl- or arsacyclopentadienylcalcium chloride complexes (av 2.715 Å), but are longer than those observed for [CH(CMeNAr-2,6- i Pr2)2CaCl·THF]2 (av 2.681 Å). The Ca−O bond distances (2.417(3) and 2.489(2) Å) are in the expected range for THF (e.g., 2.337−2.619 Å in (dpp-Bian)Ca(THF)3 and (dpp-Bian)Ca(THF)4). The imido C1−N1 (1.473(4) Å) and C2−N2 (1.379(4) Å) distances are elongated compared to those (1.280(3) and 1.279(3) Å) in the neutral ligand L iPr. Meanwhile, the C1−C2 bond is shortened to 1.354(4) Å in complex 1 from 1.498(3) Å in the neutral ligand. These distances indicate that the ligands in complex 1 have the negative valence of −1.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

[(L iPr)-Ca(μ2-Cl)(THF)2]2 (1)

Reaction of (L iPr)-Na with 1 equiv of CaCl2 gave the dinuclear complex 1. Single crystals for X-ray diffraction studies were grown from THF (Figure ). There is a crystallographic inversion center in complex 1, which is located at the center of the rectangular Ca'-Cl-Ca-Cl' plane. The Ca⋅⋅⋅Ca separation is 4.263(1) Å. Each Ca atom is six-coordinated by the two N donors of a ligand, two bridging Cl atoms, and two THF molecules. The two Ca-N bonds are significantly nonequivalent, with Ca-N1 (2.575(3) Å) being longer than Ca-N2 (2.372(3) Å). The Ca-Cl bond lengths (2.7145(11) and 2.7521(11) Å) are close to the values found for related compounds [1,2,4-( t Bu)3CpCaCl⋅DME]2 (av 2.746 Å) and phosphacyclopentadienyl- or arsacyclopentadienylcalcium chloride complexes (av 2.715 Å), but are longer than those observed for [CH(CMeNAr-2,6- i Pr2)2CaCl⋅THF]2 (av 2.681 Å). The Ca-O bond distances (2.417(3) and 2.489(2) Å) are in the expected range for THF (e.g., 2.337-2.619 Å in (dpp-Bian)Ca(THF)3 and (dpp-Bian)Ca(THF)4). The imido C1-N1 (1.473(4) Å) and C2-N2 (1.379(4) Å) distances are elongated compared to those (1.280(3) and 1.279(3) Å) in the neutral ligand L iPr. Meanwhile, the C1-C2 bond is shortened to 1.354(4) Å in complex 1 from 1.498(3) Å in the neutral ligand. These distances indicate that the ligands in complex 1 have the negative valence of -1.

elements.content: In the five-membered chelating ring, the Ca atom is located slightly out of the plane defined by N1C1C2N2, with a vertical distance of 0.49 Å between Ca and the N1C1C2N2 plane and a dihedral angle of 14.4° between planes N1CaN2 and N1C1C2N2. The two C2N2 planes adopt a parallel but non-coplanar orientation (with a vertical separation of ca. 0.94 Å). The dihedral angles between the central C2N2 moiety and the two terminal substituted aryl groups in complex 1 are significantly different (89.6° and 70.4°, respectively), which might be caused by the steric repulsion of the THF molecules and the i Pr groups.

elements.content: The reaction of the sodium salt of the mesityl-substituted ligand, (LMes)−Na, with 1 equiv of CaCl2 yielded the dimeric complex 2 bridged by chloride ions. The crystal structure of 2 is similar to 1 as a centrosymmetric complex (Figure ). The C−N (1.323(3), 1.347(3) Å) bond distances are elongated, while the C−C (1.432(3) Å) bond is shortened, and these distances indicate the monoanionic character of the ligand in complex 2. Each CaII ion also interacts with two N atoms, two bridging Cl atoms, and two THF molecules. As in complex 1, the Ca atom sits over the C2N2 moiety with a vertical distance of 0.45 Å and a dihedral angle of 12.8° between planes N1CaN2 and N1C1C2N2. The mean Ca−N (2.41575 Å), Ca−Cl (2.7369 Å), and Ca−O (2.44795 Å) bond lengths in 2 are comparable to those in 1 (2.4735, 2.7333, and 2.453 Å, respectively). Moreover, the N−Ca−N (68.84°) and O−Ca−O (88.39°) angles are very close to those in 1, while the Cl−Ca−Cl angle is slightly larger, by 5.37°. There are some minor structural differences between 1 and 2. The Ca···Ca′ separation of 4.1037(8) Å and the vertical separation of ca. 0.94 Å between the two C2N2 planes in 2 are shorter than those in 1 by ca. 0.13 and 0.30 Å, respectively. Furthermore, the dihedral angles between the central C2N2 moiety and the two terminal aryl groups in complex 2 are nearly the same (78.07° and 76.97°, respectively), while in 1 they are different, as mentioned above. These differences may be attributed to the smaller steric hindrance of the methyl groups in 2 than the ortho isopropyl analogue 1.

elements.content: Both complexes 1 and 2 contain two monoanionic ligands and are thus paramagnetic biradical species. This is reflected in their 1H NMR spectra in C6D6, which display no accurate signals in the region corresponding to the ligand. Furthermore, the solid-state EPR spectrum of 1 (Figure ) shows the expected paramagnetic signal centered at g = 2.008, which is similar to those reported for metal complexes containing radical anionic diimine ligands. A similar diiodide-bridged calcium compound, [(dpp-Bian)CaI(THF)2]2, was also reported previously. The Ca−N, N−C, and C−C bond distances in the three complexes are very close to each other.

elements.content: The reaction of the potassium salt of the dianionic ligand L iPr [(L iPr)2-K2] and 0.5 equiv of CaCl2 in THF yielded an unusual polymeric helical chain structure, which crystallizes in the chiral space group C2221 (Figure ). In the crystal structure of 3, the CaII ion resides at a C 2 axis and is coordinated by four N atoms of two ligands in a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The dihedral angle between the two C2N2 moieties is 66.82°. The Ca−N distances (2.307(5) and 2.324(4) Å) are shorter than those in complexes 1 and 2. The Ca atom is located out of the C2N2 plane, with a vertical distance of 1.372 Å and a dihedral angle of 49.60°. This differs greatly from the situation in 1 (Ca deviates 0.45 Å) and 2 (Ca deviates 0.49 Å). The distances of the C−N (1.413(7) and 1.435(7) Å) and C−C (1.365(8) Å) bonds in 3 fall into the range for dianionic α-diimines.

[Ca(L iPr)2- 2K2(THF)] n  (3)

The reaction of the potassium salt of the dianionic ligand L iPr [(L iPr)2-K2] and 0.5 equiv of CaCl2 in THF yielded an unusual polymeric helical chain structure, which crystallizes in the chiral space group C2221 (Figure ). In the crystal structure of 3, the CaII ion resides at a C 2 axis and is coordinated by four N atoms of two ligands in a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The dihedral angle between the two C2N2 moieties is 66.82°. The Ca-N distances (2.307(5) and 2.324(4) Å) are shorter than those in complexes 1 and 2. The Ca atom is located out of the C2N2 plane, with a vertical distance of 1.372 Å and a dihedral angle of 49.60°. This differs greatly from the situation in 1 (Ca deviates 0.45 Å) and 2 (Ca deviates 0.49 Å). The distances of the C-N (1.413(7) and 1.435(7) Å) and C-C (1.365(8) Å) bonds in 3 fall into the range for dianionic α-diimines.

elements.content: As in many complexes containing the dianionic α-diimine ligands, two K+ ions are incorporated in complex 3 to compensate the charge of the [CaL2]2− unit. The two K+ ions exhibit significantly different coordination modes. One of them (K1) is solvated by a THF molecule and forms a total of six intramolecular K−C bonds (2.997 to 3.254 Å) with two phenyl rings from two ligands within one [CaL2] unit. These two aryl rings, each providing an η3-coordination with K+ by using the ipso- and two ortho-carbon atoms, are not perpendicular but largely flattened to the central C2N2 plane (dihedral angle 59.39°). The other K+ cation (K2) is sandwiched by two phenyl rings in two separated [CaL2] units through 12 intermolecular K−C bonds (3.016 to 3.185 Å). The two coordinating phenyl rings, however, remain in the perpendicular position relative to the central C2N2 plane (dihedral angle 83.15°) (Figure a).

The other K+ cation (K2) is sandwiched by two phenyl rings in two separated [CaL2] units through 12 intermolecular K-C bonds (3.016 to 3.185 Å). elements.content: Through these “intermolecular” K−C contacts, each [Ca(L iPr)2− 2K2] unit is linked to two neighbors to form an infinite left-handed 21 helical chain along the c-axis with a helical pitch of 16.275 Å (Figure b and c). This aggregation is remarkably different from the polymeric zinc(II) complex [K2(THF)Zn(LEt)2] n , in which each [ZnL2K2] unit is linked to four adjacent molecules, resulting in a two-dimensional network. The helical chains are further packed in a parallel fashion through weak interactions in the extended structure. Notably, the whole packing structure of this compound comprises only left-handed helices, giving a homochiral superstructure. The formation of the helical chain is unique and suggests that novel polymeric structures may be constructed in these systems. We have also attempted the reaction of the sodium salt [(L iPr)2−Na2] and CaCl2, but have not isolated any products.

elements.content: Under similar conditions, when the mesityl-substituted dianionic ligand (LMes)Na2 was used to react with CaCl2 (0.5 equiv) in THF, the mononuclear calcium complex 4 was obtained (Figure ). Like the potassium analogue 3, complex 4 also contains both the alkali metal (Na+) and alkaline earth metal (Ca2+) ions in a Ca:M:L ratio of 1:2:2. However, their structures are significantly different. In the case of complex 4, the Na+ ion is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of a chelating ligand, forming a five-membered ring (Na−N1 2.468(3) Å, Na−N2 2.529(3) Å, N1−Na−N2 68.17(9)°) where the sodium atom deviates from the C2N2 plane by 1.592 Å and 50.33°. The Ca2+ ion, however, is sandwiched between two Na-metallocycles via η4-bonding to the N−CC−N moieties of the ligands, with a vertical deviation of 1.775 Å from the C2N2 plane. Here the Na-metallocycles can be regarded as analogues of the cyclopentadienyl group, and complex 4 is indeed a metallocene-like structure. The N−C and C−C bond lengths within the Na-metallocycles reflect the dianionic character of the α-diimine ligands, and the torsion angle between C1−C3 and C2−C4 is about 4.0°.

elements.content: A similar sandwich calcium complex containing Li-metallocycles of a related ligand, [(dpp-Bian)Li]2Ca, was previously reported in the literature. Compared to this compound, the Ca−N distances in complex 4 are shorter (2.380(3) and 2.370(3) Å in 4 and 2.417(2)−2.434(2) Å in the reported compound). Another difference is that in complex 4 each sodium ion of the anionic metallocycles is further solvated by two THF molecules, while in the lithium-containing complex [(dpp-Bian)Li]2Ca the smaller alkali metal ions are solvent-free. Moreover, the calcium atom in complex 4 resides on a crystallographic inversion center, while the compound [(dpp-Bian)Li]2Ca lacks this crystal-imposed symmetry.

elements.content: The reaction of the dilithium salt (L iPr)Li2 with CaCl2 in THF gave the product 5 (space group C2/c), which has a dimeric structure with two [Ca(L)2−Li(THF)(μ3-Cl)Li(THF)2(μ3-Cl)] moieties connected by two μ3-Cl bridges (Figure ). A crystallographic inversion center resides on the center of the four-membered Ca2Cl2 ring. The Ca atom is η4-bonded to the N−CC−N moiety of one ligand and three bridging chloride ions with different Ca−Cl distances at 2.7224(13), 2.9699(14), and 2.7179(14) Å. The mean Ca−N bond length (2.393 Å) is comparable to that in 4 (2.375 Å), but is shorter than that in 1 (2.474 Å) and 2 (2.416 Å). The Ca−Cl bond length (av 2.803 Å) is slightly longer than that in 1 (2.733 Å) and 2 (2.737 Å).

[Ca(L iPr)2-Li(THF)(μ3-Cl)Li(THF)2(μ3-Cl)]2 (5)

The reaction of the dilithium salt (L iPr)Li2 with CaCl2 in THF gave the product 5 (space group C2/c), which has a dimeric structure with two [Ca(L)2-Li(THF)(μ3-Cl)Li(THF)2(μ3-Cl)] moieties connected by two μ3-Cl bridges (Figure ). A crystallographic inversion center resides on the center of the four-membered Ca2Cl2 ring. The Ca atom is η4-bonded to the N-CC-N moiety of one ligand and three bridging chloride ions with different Ca-Cl distances at 2.7224(13), 2.9699(14), and 2.7179(14) Å. The mean Ca-N bond length (2.393 Å) is comparable to that in 4 (2.375 Å), but is shorter than that in 1 (2.474 Å) and 2 (2.416 Å). The Ca-Cl bond length (av 2.803 Å) is slightly longer than that in 1 (2.733 Å) and 2 (2.737 Å).

elements.content: Complex 5 features a laddered Ca2Li2Cl4 moiety that contains two different types of Li+ ions and μ3-bridging chloride ions. Each of the inversion-related Cl(1) and Cl(1′) atoms connects two Ca atoms and one Li atom (Li1), while each of Cl(2) and Cl(2′) bridges one Ca and two Li atoms. The two types of Li atoms are both four-coordinate, with Li2 being coordinated by two N donors of one ligand, one chloride ion, and one THF molecule in a severely distorted tetrahedral arrangement, and with Li1 bonded by two Cl atoms and two THF molecules with a tetrahedral geometry. This tetrametallic moiety is composed of three four-membered rings, which are roughly coplanar and are in a ladder-shaped arrangement. The central tetragon of Ca, Cl(1), Cl(1′), and Ca′ is planar with a Cl(1)−Ca-Cl(1′) angle of 74.46(4)°. The Li2−Cl(2) bond distance (2.613(9) Å) is obviously longer than the Li1−Cl(1) and Li1−Cl(2) bonds (2.360(9) and 2.328(9) Å), but they are all comparable to the Li−Cl contacts in some reported compounds containing chloride-bridged Li atoms (ca. 2.30 to 2.78 Å).

elements.content: In complex 5, a long−short−long sequence of the N−CC−N bond lengths is observed, which is diagnostic of the dianionic form of the α-diimine ligand. The Li-metallocycle is also an isoelectronic analogue of the Cp group, like the [C2N2Na] moiety in complex 4 and [C2N2Li] in [(dpp-Bian)Li]2Ca. The Li2 atom, which is coordinated by one diimine ligand, is located out of the N1C1C2N2 plane, with a vertical distance of 0.752 Å and a dihedral angle of 27.99°. On the other hand, the η4-bonded calcium atom deviates largely from the C2N2 plane (vertical distance 1.921 Å). The Li−N bonds (2.095(8) and 2.104(8) Å) are slightly longer than those in [(dpp-Bian)Li]2Ca (2.011(6)−2.033(5) Å).

elements.content: A comparison of the structures of the calcium complexes 1−5 and related compounds is necessary in order to get deeper insight into the structural features of these compounds. As mentioned above, when the α-diimine ligands are reduced to the dianionic form, an alkali metal ion is often attached to the ligand besides other metal ions, which are coordinated by the ligand. In such systems, the two metal ions show different coordination modes according to their electronic properties. For example, in the Zn complexes, whether the zinc atom is in the +2 or +1 oxidation state, it is unexceptionally coordinated in the N,N-chelating mode, whereas the sodium or potassium ions are either η4-bonded by the NCCN moiety or by the aryl groups. However, if both alkali metal and alkaline earth metal ions are involved, the situation is more complicated. In the Mg−Mg-bonded compound [K(THF)3]2[(L iPr)Mg−Mg(L iPr)]·2THF, the Mg+ ion is chelated by the N,N-donors of the dianionic diimine ligand and the K+ ions are η4-bonded by the NCCN moiety. This is similar to the cases of the Zn+ or Zn2+ compounds. In contrast, when the magnesium ion is replaced by calcium, as in the above-mentioned complexes 3, 4, and 5, it appears that the Ca2+ ion tends to interact with all four atoms of the C2N2 moiety of the dianionic ligands, leaving the alkali metal ion (K+, Na+, and Li+) to be coordinated only by the N,N-donors. This tendency is reflected in the structural parameters such as the deviation of the calcium atom from the C2N2 plane. In complex 3, though the calcium atom forms contacts only with the N atoms, it deviates significantly from the C2N2 plane (1.372 Å and 49.60°), which can be regarded as an intermediate between the planar N,N-chelating and the η4-bonding modes. On the other hand, the potassium ions in 3 are involved in K−C bonding. In the sodium analogue 4 and lithium compound 5, the Ca2+ ions are formally η4-bonded by all four C2N2 atoms, with vertical deviations of 1.775 and 1.921 Å from the C2N2 plane, respectively. Meanwhile, the sodium or lithium ion is located more planar with the chelating ring, with deviations of 1.592 and 0.752 Å, respectively. From these results, it may be tentatively concluded that the electropositive ions (e.g., Na+, K+, Ca2+) prefer to contact with the doubly charged C2N2 moiety, whereas the less electropositive ones (Mg+, Zn2+, Zn+) tend to be chelated in the normal fashion albeit with noticeable deviations from coplanarity of the chelating ring. This is further proved by the [Na2L] complexes, in which both coordination forms of the sodium ion are observed.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of the Coordination Modes of the Alkali and Alkaline Earth Metals in 1-5 and Related Compounds

A comparison of the structures of the calcium complexes 1-5 and related compounds is necessary in order to get deeper insight into the structural features of these compounds. As mentioned above, when the α-diimine ligands are reduced to the dianionic form, an alkali metal ion is often attached to the ligand besides other metal ions, which are coordinated by the ligand. In such systems, the two metal ions show different coordination modes according to their electronic properties. For example, in the Zn complexes, whether the zinc atom is in the +2 or +1 oxidation state, it is unexceptionally coordinated in the N,N-chelating mode, whereas the sodium or potassium ions are either η4-bonded by the NCCN moiety or by the aryl groups. However, if both alkali metal and alkaline earth metal ions are involved, the situation is more complicated. In the Mg-Mg-bonded compound [K(THF)3]2[(L iPr)Mg-Mg(L iPr)]⋅2THF, the Mg+ ion is chelated by the N,N-donors of the dianionic diimine ligand and the K+ ions are η4-bonded by the NCCN moiety. This is similar to the cases of the Zn+ or Zn2+ compounds. In contrast, when the magnesium ion is replaced by calcium, as in the above-mentioned complexes 3, 4, and 5, it appears that the Ca2+ ion tends to interact with all four atoms of the C2N2 moiety of the dianionic ligands, leaving the alkali metal ion (K+, Na+, and Li+) to be coordinated only by the N,N-donors. This tendency is reflected in the structural parameters such as the deviation of the calcium atom from the C2N2 plane. In complex 3, though the calcium atom forms contacts only with the N atoms, it deviates significantly from the C2N2 plane (1.372 Å and 49.60°), which can be regarded as an intermediate between the planar N,N-chelating and the η4-bonding modes. On the other hand, the potassium ions in 3 are involved in K-C bonding. In the sodium analogue 4 and lithium compound 5, the Ca2+ ions are formally η4-bonded by all four C2N2 atoms, with vertical deviations of 1.775 and 1.921 Å from the C2N2 plane, respectively. Meanwhile, the sodium or lithium ion is located more planar with the chelating ring, with deviations of 1.592 and 0.752 Å, respectively. From these results, it may be tentatively concluded that the electropositive ions (e.g., Na+, K+, Ca2+) prefer to contact with the doubly charged C2N2 moiety, whereas the less electropositive ones (Mg+, Zn2+, Zn+) tend to be chelated in the normal fashion albeit with noticeable deviations from coplanarity of the chelating ring. This is further proved by the [Na2L] complexes, in which both coordination forms of the sodium ion are observed.

We report the synthesis and structures of five calcium complexes with redox noninnocent α-diimine ligands. The reaction of the doubly reduced ligands with calcium dichloride did not cause the reduction of the divalent Ca2+ ion to the subvalent Ca+, and the ligands remained the original charges in the products. Using different substituents (2,6-diisopropylphenyl or 2,4,6-trimethylphenyl) on the ligands, reducing agents, and reaction conditions resulted in varying and unusual structures, such as the chloride-bridged dimers 1 and 2, the left-handed 21 helix 3, the metallocene-like structure 4, and the laddered structure of 5. The different coordination modes of the alkali metal ions and Ca2+ appear to be related to the relative electropositive properties of the metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We report the synthesis and structures of five calcium complexes with redox noninnocent α-diimine ligands. The reaction of the doubly reduced ligands with calcium dichloride did not cause the reduction of the divalent Ca2+ ion to the subvalent Ca+, and the ligands remained the original charges in the products. Using different substituents (2,6-diisopropylphenyl or 2,4,6-trimethylphenyl) on the ligands, reducing agents, and reaction conditions resulted in varying and unusual structures, such as the chloride-bridged dimers 1 and 2, the left-handed 21 helix 3, the metallocene-like structure 4, and the laddered structure of 5. The different coordination modes of the alkali metal ions and Ca2+ appear to be related to the relative electropositive properties of the metal ions.

Tetrahydrofuran was dried by sodium/benzophenone and distilled under argon prior to use. The alkali metal salts of the ligands LM n (L = L iPr or LMes; M = Na or K; n = 1 or 2) were prepared as previously described. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker DPX-200 NMR spectrometer (400 MHz).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

All manipulations were carried out under an inert atmosphere using Schlenk or drybox techniques. Tetrahydrofuran was dried by sodium/benzophenone and distilled under argon prior to use. The alkali metal salts of the ligands LM n  (L = L iPr or LMes; M = Na or K; n = 1 or 2) were prepared as previously described. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker DPX-200 NMR spectrometer (400 MHz).

elements.content: CaCl2 (0.28 g, 2.52 mmol) was added to a rigorously stirred solution of (L iPr)−Na in THF [prepared in situ from L (1.00 g, 2.47 mmol) and sodium (0.06 g, 2.60 mmol)]. The mixture was stirred for 3 days at room temperature. It was then filtered and the filtrate concentrated to about 30 mL. Slow evaporation of the solution at ambient temperature for several days yielded the product as yellow crystals (0.16 g, 10%). Anal. Calcd for C72H112Ca2Cl2N4O4 (1248.75): C, 69.25; H, 9.04; N, 4.49. Found: C, 69.53; H, 9.21; N, 4.56.

CaCl2 (0.28 g, 2.52 mmol) was added to a rigorously stirred solution of (L iPr)-Na in THF [prepared in situ from L (1.00 g, 2.47 mmol) and sodium (0.06 g, 2.60 mmol)]. The mixture was stirred for 3 days at room temperature. It was then filtered and the filtrate concentrated to about 30 mL. Slow evaporation of the solution at ambient temperature for several days yielded the product as yellow crystals (0.16 g, 10%). Anal. Calcd for C72H112Ca2Cl2N4O4 (1248.75): C, 69.25; H, 9.04; N, 4.49. Found: C, 69.53; H, 9.21; N, 4.56.

elements.content: Compound 2 was synthesized in a similar way to 1, from CaCl2 (0.28 g, 2.52 mmol) and (LMes)−Na [prepared in situ from L (0.80 g, 2.50 mmol) and sodium (0.06 g, 2.60 mmol)]. Yield: 0.14 g (10%). Anal. Calcd for C60H88Ca2Cl2N4O4 (1080.43): C, 66.70; H, 8.21; N, 5.19. Found: C, 66.34; H, 7.98; N, 4.85.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [(LMes)-Ca(μ2-Cl)(THF)2]2 (LMes = [(2,4,6-Me3C6H2)NC(Me)]2) (2)

Compound 2 was synthesized in a similar way to 1, from CaCl2 (0.28 g, 2.52 mmol) and (LMes)-Na [prepared in situ from L (0.80 g, 2.50 mmol) and sodium (0.06 g, 2.60 mmol)]. Yield: 0.14 g (10%). Anal. Calcd for C60H88Ca2Cl2N4O4 (1080.43): C, 66.70; H, 8.21; N, 5.19. Found: C, 66.34; H, 7.98; N, 4.85.

elements.content: CaCl2 (0.27 g, 2.43 mmol) was added to a THF solution (50 mL) of (L iPr)2-K2 [prepared in situ from L iPr (1.00 g, 2.47 mmol) and potassium (0.19 g, 4.94 mmol)], and the mixture was stirred for 5 days. It was then filtered and the filtrate concentrated to about 30 mL and stored at ca. −20 °C for several days to yield the product as yellow crystals (0.18 g, 15%). A 1H NMR spectrum of this compound could not be obtained due to the poor solubility of the polymeric structure. Anal. Calcd for C60H88CaK2N4O (999.64): C, 72.09; H, 8.87; N, 5.60. Found: C, 71.81; H, 8.77; N, 5.62.

elements.content: Diffraction data for complexes 1−5 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer at room temperature (293 K) with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). An empirical absorption correction using SADABS was applied for all data. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 by the use of the program SHELXL. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in idealized geometric positions with thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. In the compounds 3, 4, and 5, some C and O atoms on the THF molecules show quite large thermal vibrations. Crystallographic data for 1−5 are listed in Table . CCDC numbers: − (for 1, 2, 4, and 5) and (3). These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Determination

Diffraction data for complexes 1-5 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer at room temperature (293 K) with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). An empirical absorption correction using SADABS was applied for all data. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 by the use of the program SHELXL. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in idealized geometric positions with thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. In the compounds 3, 4, and 5, some C and O atoms on the THF molecules show quite large thermal vibrations. Crystallographic data for 1-5 are listed in Table . CCDC numbers: - (for 1, 2, 4, and 5) and  (3). These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK).

The mixture was stirred for 3 days at room temperature. It was then filtered and the filtrate concentrated to about 30 mL. Slow evaporation of the solution at ambient temperature for several days yielded the product as yellow crystals (0.16 g, 10%). Anal. Calcd for C72H112Ca2Cl2N4O4 (1248.75): C, 69.25; H, 9.04; N, 4.49.
